definition.en: An analytical procedure run without a "substitute material" and results obtained are considered to be the "analytical blank". Example 1: An acid digestion procedure is run without a sample, to show level of impurities introduced by the acids and the digestion vessels used.
Anthropogenic material originating from human activity
A part of a grain which is the subject of a detailed analysis via a microprobe beam of electrons or energised ions.
Terrestrial sediment specimen sampled from close to the lower boundary of a hydrologic catchment; may have an aeolian component mixed in with fluvial sediments.
A specimen of unconsolidated materials (eg, regolith, sediment, gravel, soil) collected by any method at or near the ground surface, including soil and organic matter.

Drill chips/cuttings material that is foreign to the depth interval sampled and most likely derived from higher in the stratigraphic column or possibly recirculated within the mud system from previous drilling activity.
Rock or sediment chips or fragments derived from any drilling method.
A float specimen collected along the coastline, usually washed up on beaches. (eg, coastal bitumen).
A specimen taken of an isolated fragment or rock or other consolidated earth material, displaced from its original outcrop or location.

A sample, usually of unconsolidated materials, collected in a coastal environment by any method. May include sediment, rocks, water, and/or organic matter. Coastal is here defined as any location above Lowest Astronomical Tide
A small plug (cylinder) of core, typically taken from a larger rock or core sample (ie, a sub-sample)
A specimen (often, but not always cylindrical) of rock, regolith, or vegetation.
A section of core that represents a specified depth interval, typically cut from a larger core specimen.
A coarse crushed sample.
A fluid sample retrieved from a downhole formation test (WFT)
Fluid used for drill bit lubrication and return of ground rock material from the drill bit, e.g. drilling mud.
Any specimen of material taken from a borehole. Only used where no other information about the borehole specimen type is available.
Any specimen of material taken from a field site (eg, rock, sediment, water, hydrocarbon). This generic value is only used where no other information about the specimen type is available.
A water column specimen filtered for suspended solids.
A water specimen taken at measured intervals in the water column.
A fluid-filled inclusion in a rock or mineral (may also contain vapour and solids at room temperature).
A thick section used to examine tiny inclusions of liquid, vapour, solid, or mixtures of these phases, trapped as impurities within mineral grains.
A specimen of unconsolidated gravel size regolith material.
A cylindrical drill core which has been cut in half parallel to its length.
A water sample collected from a chamber or core incubation for the purpose of use of profiling the water column.
A generic specimen of water of any type. Includes water specimen types collected by any method.
A glassy inclusion in a rock or mineral (may also contain liquid, vapour and crystals at room temperature).
A slide prepared for microscope analysis of microfossils.
A specimen of remains or traces of a plant or animal preserved in the Earth's crust.
An individual mineralogical particle, usually isolated from a thin section, or mounted with other grains in a polished mount.
A collection of one or more minerals precipitated from solution (eg, salt crust or gypsum crystals precipitated on a salt lake).
A collection of mineral grains separated using density and magnetic contrast from other mineral grains.
A form of substance which has had the majority of its base component (in the case of a liquid: the solvent) removed. Typically this will be the removal of water from a solution or suspension
A high quality or type mineral specimen, collected for scientific or display purposes in a museum or similar setting

A description of a sampling feature in a continuous linear format (e.g. stratigraphic or lithology logs for boreholes and measured sections), where the observation description is not related to a specific collected specimen
An observation made of a field site (eg, an outcrop), without collection of a physical specimen.
An observation made of a feature, without collection of a physical specimen.
A drill core specimen taken with its orientation preserved to enable structural or other oriented analysis.
An outcrop specimen taken with its orientation preserved to enable structural or geophysical analysis.
A specimen of material removed from outcropping or near-outcropping bedrock. Includes subterranean rock outcrops (ie, from a mine).
A specimen that has been ground into a powder and pressed into a pellet.
A digital or film photographic still image
Materials mounted in a medium, typically an epoxy glue or resin, and polished.
A polished slab of rock material.
A polished thin section of a material for microscope analysis.
A translucent thin section of a material for microscope analysis.
A specimen that has been ground into a powder.
A specimen that has been ground into a powder in a tungsten alloy mill.
A cylindrical drill core which has been cut in quarters parallel to its length.
Repeat specimen taken in the field over given space and/or time scales to test field heterogeneity of a sampling medium.  Should be related to a previous original specimen.
A repeat analytical specimen designed to replicate the original specimen type and method of sample preparation and/or collection. Should be related to a previous original specimen.
Identical split(s) of an original sample submitted blindly to the laboratory to test reproducibility (bias) of results.  Should be related to a previous original specimen.
An unspecified residue from a sample preparation or analytical technique.
Rock fragments derived from crushing or chipping material other than by drilling (eg, chips from an outcrop or mine channel sampling).
Unspecified rock samples or fragments of rock of unknown origin.
Specimens of surficial seafloor sediments obtained by sub-sampling the contents of a grab or box core. Depending on the intended analyses, these may be volumetric, gravimetric or qualitative.

A sample, usually of unconsolidated materials, collected on the seabed by any method. May include sediment, rocks, water, and/or organic matter. Seabed is here defined as any location below Lowest Astronomical Tide
Liquid that has been separated from a gas phase at a surface separator.
A specimen that has been modified to be a specific fraction separated from the original sample eg. a panned or separated sample.
A grainsize fraction specimen generated by sieving
A specimen that has been generated by separating various size fractions from the original sample. For example, a sieved sediment sample.
A specimen of soil or similar regolith materials, collected by any method.

A specimen blank is used to determine if any impurities are introduced during sample preparation procedures. A "sample blank material" substitutes regular "sample material" in the procedure. Example 1: Quartz substitutes a rock sample to determine levels of impurities introduced by grinding equipment. Example 2: Cellulose substitutes vegetable material to determine levels of impurities introduced during sample preparation. Example 3: Pure deionized water is substituted for sample water to determine if impurities are introduced during sample filtering and bottling procedures.

Also known as SRM,  these samples may range from International Standards and Certified Reference Materials (CRMs) to locally prepared standard samples for use as project reference standards. They are comprised of homogenous material prepared under strict guidelines, divided into numerous aliquots and sent to reputable laboratories to derive an assigned value. The values for Standard Reference Materials are generally well known published figures. SRMs with certified values are used to calibrate instruments or analytical techniques, to quantify analytical accuracy, and to verify new or improved analytical techniques. The material of the reference standard (eg, rock, mineral, water, etc) should be denoted in "material type".
A specimen, often a rock slab, that has been stained for mineral idenification.
A sample of sediment taken from the bed of a river or stream.
A small slab of rock remaining from the preparation of a thin section.
The sample type is unknown
A specimen of vegetation collected by any method.
A digital or film capture of a sequence of still images representing scenes in motion
A polished slab, mount, or slide for analysing vitrinite reflectance.

An observation or measurement of the water column recorded by a sonde/probe, typically taken at measured intervals used to profile the water column. No actual specimen is collected but the observation records the water conditions at a particular time and place.
A continuous log of measurements made by an instrument in a borehole.
A 110ml aluminium cylinder used to collect and store gas from a sampling manifold on a borehole druing mudgas logging. A product of ISOTECH Laboratories.
A generic specimen of gas of any type. Includes gas specimen types collected by any method.
Natural gas that has been separated from a liquid phase at a surface separator.
